tossups.question: A poem by this author describes how the “The fusty showman fumbles, must / Fit in a particle of dust / The universe,” and includes the section “The Ape Watches ‘Aunt Sally.’” The title character of a poem by this author is “Tall as a stork” and would “stalk with a gun / the reynard-colored sun.” The supposedly real-life story of Lord Rokeby, who bathed continuously throughout his life, appears in this author’s collection English Eccentrics. The anthology The (*) Canticle of the Rose collects the poems of this author, who wrote the lines “Dark as the world of man, black as our loss / Blind as 1940 nails upon the cross” in response to the London Blitz. She edited the annual anthology Wheels with her brothers Sacheverell and Oswald, and used a megaphone to recite her most famous series of poems, which were accompanied by music composed by William Walton. For 10 points, name this English poet of “Still Falls the Rain” and Façade.
tossups.answer: Dame Edith (Louisa) Sitwell <Literature - British>

tossups.question: Using medieval examples of these objects often required employing the “rule of marteloio,” although no one has any idea who or what “marteloio” was. Examples of these objects meant for religious propaganda include Heinrich Bunting’s clover design and a type named for Beatus of Liébana. Trendy sixteenth-century French nobility loved luxury examples of these objects produced in Dieppe. Abraham Crescas led a school of Majorcan Jews that produced the (*) “portolan” type of these things. Symbolic of examples of these things often used a “T and O” format, while a practical medieval type of these objects is characterized by visual aids inaccurately called “rhumb lines.” A seated Mansa Musa is depicted on the “Catalan” one. One of these works named for Piri Reis centers on the Atlantic, while the one created by Martin Waldseemüller is the first to use the name “America.” For 10 points, name these objects, modern examples of which often still use the controversial Mercator projection.
tossups.answer: maps [accept any of nautical charts, atlases, mappae mundi, globes, or planispheres; accept maps of specific places or things; accept compasses, sextants, sails, or even just boats or parts thereof until “Bunting,” but do not accept or prompt after] <History - European>

tossups.question: It’s not momentum, but when the renormalization group rescalings are performed on integrals over these entities, new terms in the Hamiltonian do not appear. In the special relativistic analog of this entity, the angle between the time-like and transformed space-like components is the angle whose cosine appears in the formula for the Doppler shift. In statistical physics a sum over them is replaced with an integral over the space of these things with measure equal to the (*) density of states, which is subsequently replaced with an integral over energy levels and evaluated. In general, the gradient of the circular frequency with respect to this mathematical object is the group velocity. This quantity dotted into the spatial displacement is one of the terms in the phase. For a particle in a box, allowable values of this entity are 2-pi over the length of the box times an integer vector. For 10 points, name this physical quantity symbolized with a bold lowercase k.
tossups.answer: wave vector [or wave number vector; accept wave number 4-vector; prompt on k; prompt on wave number] <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: In the first scene of this play’s second act, a character shakes an old fur cloak, producing a chorus of chanting insects. A philosopher in this play asks the moon to descend from the sky to save pygmies from a flock of cranes, but the moon instead sends a meteor that destroys the pygmies’ mountain. Its third act begins in unrhymed trimeter, in keeping with its ancient setting, until the arrival of a modern character causes it to switch to blank verse. A character in this play dies when the (*) glass flask he lives in shatters during a ceremony presided over by Proteus; that homunculus was created by Wagner. The title character of this play has a son named Euphorion with Helen of Troy. At its conclusion, Mater Gloriosa leads the title character into heaven, and a Chorus Mysticus ends this play with the line: “The Eternal Feminine / Lead us on high.” For 10 points, name this last completed work of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, a sequel to an earlier play about a scholar who makes a deal with the Devil.
tossups.answer: Faust, Part Two [or Faust, The Second Part of the Tragedy; or Faust. Der Tragödie zweiter Teil in fünf Akten; both parts required in all cases, prompt on partial answers like Faust] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. According to one critic, the first appearance of this plot detail is superior to its second appearance because the first is “linked to reversal” while the second is “for the sake of proof.” Another critic argued that a scene revealing this plot detail demonstrates its author’s tendency to keep events always in the foreground, unlike another text, which is “fraught with background.” That critic contrasted the “reality” of a scene centering on this detail with the “tyrannical” need to represent truth in the Binding of Isaac episode of Genesis. A key moment of (*) anagnorisis caused by the sight of this plot detail is analyzed in the first chapter of Erich Auerbach’s Mimesis, which is named for it. It was acquired in a boar hunt on Mount Parnassus, and is spotted by a nurse while she bathes the feet of a man disguised as a beggar. For 10 points, name this detail that allows Eurycleia to identify her former master in an epic poem by Homer.
tossups.answer: Odysseus’s scar <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: Sets of badges and medals created on behalf of this family were the best-known creations of Albert Keibel. Academic artist Carl Timoleon von Neff and Baroque painter Louis Caravaque both served as portraitists for members of this family. The Bouquet of Lilies Clock and the Blue Serpent Clock were designed for members of this family. Six priests in bright gold robes dominate the left-hand side of a wedding portrait painted for this family by Laurits Tuxen. The largest collections of a series of 52 artworks made for this family are housed in the Virginia Museum and a museum founded by (*) Viktor Vekselberg. Working for this family, Michael Perchin and Henrik Wigström designed a series of enamelled, jewel-encrusted objects that each contained a “surprise” and were given out as Easter presents. For 10 points, name this royal family for whom many bejewelled “eggs” were made by Fabergé until 1917, when they were murdered by the Bolsheviks.
tossups.answer: House of Romanov [prompt on descriptive answers like “the Russian Royal Family”] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: This thinker argued that humans engage in a “super-conscious,” rather than “subconscious,” process of recognizing complexity in an essay on the “primacy of the abstract.” This thinker borrowed an Ancient Greek concept to argue that the distinction between meum and tuum needed to be enforced via “xenos rights” for foreign investors. A recent book by Quinn Slobodian argues that this thinker’s call to “dethrone politics” was central to the Geneva School’s efforts to “encase” the economy. This thinker proposed that a (*) “spontaneous order” he termed “catallaxy” developed through the adjustment of many individual economies to the world market. An essay by this thinker critiques Oskar Lange’s ideas by claiming that resource coordination in a state of “dispersed knowledge” can only be achieved by the free market. Law, Legislation, and Liberty is a work by—for 10 points—what neoliberal economist who wrote “The Use of Knowledge in Society” and The Road to Serfdom?
tossups.answer: Friedrich von Hayek <Social Science>

tossups.question: The Athenian admiral Charimitides aided a rebel in this region who was either crucified or impaled on three stakes at the behest of the Queen Mother Amestris. Herodotus claimed that castes called Hermotybies and Kalasiries supplied this region’s main soldiers, which Greeks called machimoi. An enigmatic figure called “Khababash” harried Achaemenid rule of this region, and Amyrtaeus took advantage of Cyrus II’s civil war to briefly liberate it. This region was allegedly invaded after an eye doctor convinced a king to ask for the hand of a daughter of its ruler (*) Amasis, who instead sent the daughter of a predecessor. Questionable accounts claim that the Persians defeated troops from this region at the Battle of Pelusium by placing cats at the head of their armies. During a fit of rage, an invader of this region supposedly killed the Apis Bull. For 10 points, name this region annexed to the Achaemenid Empire by Cambyses II, ending its Third Intermediate Period’s Twenty-Sixth Dynasty.
tossups.answer: Egypt [or Aegyptos; accept Libya until “Khababash,” but do not accept or prompt after; accept the Nile Valley] (The rebel in the first sentence is Inaros II.) <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: Warning: specific term required. HITS is an algorithm developed by Jon Kleinberg that computes two measures of this quantity. To solve the problem of spider traps and dangling nodes, an algorithm that calculates one type of this measure introduces a damping factor; that algorithm simulates the actions of a random walker with added teleportation to traverse links between nodes, and has its convergence guaranteed by the Perron–Frobenius theorem. One measure of this concept is named for Leo (*) Katz, and takes into account the total number of walks, not just the shortest one. One form of this measure is calculated by following the “links” between sites in the PageRank algorithm, and it has types like “betweenness” and “closeness.” The simplest way to quantify this concept is by looking at the degree of a node. For 10 points, name this measure that quantifies a node’s importance or how close it is to the “middle” of a graph.
tossups.answer: centrality [anti-prompt on betweenness or closeness; accept specific types of centrality, as long as centrality is mentioned; accept eigencentrality; prompt on “PageRank” after “links” is read] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: This painter supposedly said “He has been here and fired a gun” after a rival added a blob of bright red to steal the show from this painter’s bright greens. This artist’s late sketches were often made entirely with a pallet knife, which he used to apply a thick impasto. Among his other techniques that produced highly visible brushstrokes, this artist scattered pure white spots across his paintings to serve as highlights. This artist’s style, which he honed by copying works by Alexander (*) Cozens, caused a bombshell at the 1824 Salon, inspiring Delacroix to repaint parts of The Massacre at Chios. This man’s habit of “skying” inspired the plein-air painting of the Barbizon school. This man’s 1819 painting The White Horse was the first of his “six-footers.” This artist depicted rainbows in late works like 1831’s Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows. For 10 points, name this English painter of The Hay Wain.
tossups.answer: John Constable <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: Founding Father James Wilson’s views on the “prerogatives of the British monarch” are dismissed in these documents as being “exceptional and atypical.” These documents, which endorse the “pride-and-ego-down approach,” were the subject of a 2009 Department of Justice report that castigated their author for failing to cite obvious precedent like Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. Philip Zelikow contends that records of his opposition to these documents were destroyed by his superiors. Jay Bybee signed these documents, for which he and their author were included in a set of (*) six officials who faced charges filed by Spanish judge Baltasar Garzón. These documents were used to justify techniques like “walling” and exploiting “stress positions.” José Padilla sued the primary author of these documents for $1, claiming they allowed his wrongful designation as an “enemy combatant.” Current Berkeley professor John Yoo authored—for 10 points—what set of legal memos written to justify “enhanced interrogation” of terrorists under the Bush administration?
tossups.answer: Bush Torture Memos [or John Yoo Torture Memos; accept just torture after “memos”] <Modern World>

tossups.question: A metal-organic framework that catalyzes this process is produced by reacting iron and nickel oxides with 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylate. Molybdenum sulfide cluster anions can act as catalysts for this process, a heterogeneous catalyst for which was made by Dan Nocera’s group, who added phosphate ions to an aqueous solution containing cobalt(II) ions and a ruthenium bipy [“bippy”] complex. In thin-film and nanoparticle form, the anatase mineral form of (*) titanium dioxide has been shown to catalyze this process in an effect discovered by Honda and Fujishima. A biomimetic calcium-manganese complex has been developed to drive this process. Exchange current densities of 10-to-the-minus-9 can be achieved by using platinum electrodes for this process, which requires 1.229 volts plus an overpotential calculable using the Tafel equation. Absorption of a photon by P680 performs—for 10 points—what process that produces oxygen and hydrogen gas by passing current through a common liquid?
tossups.answer: electrolysis of water [or oxygen evolution or water splitting or photo-oxidation of water or hydrogen production; prompt on partial answer] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: Note to moderator: please read the technical descriptions in the first two sentences slowly. A love-theme by this composer begins with a falling “D, C” over an A-flat major chord, followed by a falling “B, E” over an A-minor chord. That work by this composer begins in triplets, arpeggiating an E-flat minor-major 7 chord in a convex arc over an E-flat-minor add-6 chord arpeggiated in a concave arch. A work for string orchestra by this composer only removes the mutes for a theme that begins with very high E-flats played with repeated down-bows in the first violins, who are then joined by (*) E-naturals a diminished octave below. In 1956, this composer appeared on-screen conducting Arthur Benjamin’s Storm Cloud Cantata, in a performance whose cymbal crash is meant to cover the sound of a gunshot. His most famous collaboration was ended by the rejection of the score for Torn Curtain, after he served as “sound consultant” on a film that uses bird cries rather than music. For 10 points, who wrote the scores to The Man Who Knew Too Much, Vertigo, and Psycho?
tossups.answer: Bernard Herrmann [or Max Herman] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: In an afterword, this thinker noted that, in late Wittgenstein, “the voices that need to be… recalled to sobriety are not alien voices.” This thinker was accused of rejecting “explicitness in the setting out of argument” and other features of clear writing in the review-essay “Human Nature?” by Crispin Wright. This thinker argued that empirical Kantian concepts are actualized passively in experience, and he tweaked his definition of “rationality” to “responsiveness to reasons as such” in the essay (*) “Conceptual Capacities in Perception.” This man used the phrase “prolegomenon to a reading of Phenomenology of Spirit” to describe one of his books, which attacks the idea that the “space of reasons…extends more widely than the conceptual sphere.” In that book, this editor of Gareth Evans’s The Varieties of Reference tried to reconcile Davidson’s coherentism with the thought of his older colleague Wilfrid Sellars. For 10 points, what South African based at the University of Pittsburgh wrote Mind and World?
tossups.answer: John (Henry) McDowell <Philosophy>

tossups.question: A coup in this decade was backed by the far-right Liga Republicana society led by the Irazusta brothers. In this decade, the power company CHADE was accused of turning officials into “chadistas” via bribery, and Enzo Bordabehere was shot dead in Senate debates on a treaty granting Britain transport monopolies in exchange for guaranteed beef exports, the Roca–Runciman Treaty. This decade saw the rule of two regimes called Concordancia, one of which began with José Félix Uriburu’s coup against the Radical Civic Union and Hipólito Yrigoyen. Carlos Saavedra Lamas won a Nobel in this decade for brokering peace in a war that saw multiple battles at Fort (*) Nanawa and discredited Hans Kundt. This decade’s ubiquitous political corruption led Argentines to deride it as the “Infamous Decade.” The Chaco War occurred during—for 10 points—what decade prior to the one in which Juan Peron took power, during which Argentina’s economy struggled through the Great Depression?
tossups.answer: 1930s [accept the Infamous Decade or la Década Infame before mentioned] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: According to this school, grave sins cannot make a believer into an unbeliever, but instead create an “intermediate” position. For this school, the irreversible decisions of the Day of Judgment constitute “the promise and the threat.” One of this school’s Five Principles holds that God’s goodness constrains God to an almost mechanical kind of justice, which therefore means that the (*) will must be free. This school’s radical interpretation of God’s unity leads to the doctrine that “God’s words” could not be separate attributes, but rather that the Quran must have been created by God. Ibn Hanbal was persecuted for his opposition to this school during the mihna. This school’s name has sometimes become a slur roughly meaning “heretic” thanks to its use of Greek thought. For 10 points, name this rationalist school of Islamic theology that was briefly ascendant under the Abbasid caliphs al-Mamun and al-Mu’tasim.
tossups.answer: Mu’tazilah [accept word forms like Mu’tazilites] <Religion>

tossups.question: This author wrote a story about an aunt who’s so paranoid about being burgled that she stacks her valuables outside her bedroom door each night with a sign reading “This is all I have. Please take it and do not use your chloroform.” In a story by this author, a husband on a road trip irritates his wife by bellowing the song “Harrigan,” though she relaxes when she hears a noise indicating engine trouble. The protagonist of a third story by this author enacts revenge on a coworker for using annoying phrases like (*) “lifting the oxcart out of the ditch” and “tearing up the pea-patch.” This author of “The Night the Bed Fell” and “A Couple of Hamburgers” wrote many stories for the New Yorker, including one about a man who hears the noise “pocketa-pocketa-pocketa” while imagining conducting surgery on a millionaire and piloting a Navy hydroplane. For 10 points, name this humorist who wrote “The Catbird Seat” and “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.”
tossups.answer: James (Grover) Thurber <Literature - American>

tossups.question: The Amarna letters include ten missives from a ruler of this place named “Abi-milku,” who is sometimes linked to the Biblical Abimelech. This place is prophesied to become “a place to spread fishnets” in Ezekiel 26. A god of this city was burned and sent out to sea on a giant raft in the Egersis ceremony. A craftsman from this city named Cheiromos helped build the First Temple for Solomon, who sent a joint expedition with sailors from this city to Ophir to bring back gold. An attack on this city was repeatedly stalled using (*) fire ships. This colony of Sidon was home to Jezebel, the queen of King Ahab. This city’s king Hiram established Astarte and Melqart as its patron gods. A causeway was built out to this island city during its siege by Alexander the Great. This city’s most famous product was extracted from murex sea snails. For 10 points, name this Phoenician city known for its namesake purple dye.
tossups.answer: Tyre [or Sur or Sour or Surru] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: The most direct treatment of this condition can lead to a non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that presents similarly to ARDS and is called TRALI [“trolley”]. In susceptible individuals, this symptom can be caused by a virus with a single-stranded DNA genome that also causes a childhood exanthem in a “slapped-cheek” distribution. Its opposite can be caused by a para·neoplastic syndrome of renal cell carcinoma. Autoimmune diseases cause this general symptom because (*) hepcidin is an acute phase reactant and thus elevated in chronic immune stimulation, which is called “[this symptom] of chronic disease.” Mutations in spectrin can lead to a hereditary form of this condition called spherocytosis. High MCV and hypersegmented neutrophils are present in a form of it usually due to B12 or folate deficiency, and B12 deficiency is the culprit of its “pernicious” form. For 10 points, name this general condition most commonly caused by a lack of iron.
tossups.answer: anemia [accept more specific answers like sickle cell anemia, pernicious anemia, etc.] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: Until 2016 legal action, an offshoot of a group backing this cause enforced restrictive covenants in the Long Island town of Yaphank, where it ran a number of summer camps. Will Rogers sold Murphy Ranch to a group founded by William Dudley Pelley that supported this cause, who hoped to bring about a “Silver Revolution.” Elizabeth Dilling’s support for this cause led Francis Biddle to indict a number of members of the “Mother’s Movement” in a scandalous trial. This cause was advanced by the Home Sweet Home Hour hosted by (*) Mildred Gillars, a counterpart of Rita Zucca. Backers of this cause stormed the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung and held a 20,000-person rally at Madison Square Garden led by Fritz Kuhn. Association with this cause’s backers was the main domestic factor discrediting the America First Committee. For 10 points, name this cause advocated by the German-American Bund and by a later party founded by George Lincoln Rockwell, whose supporters sought to establish an “American Reich.”
tossups.answer: Nazism in America [prompt on answers about American fascism with “What kind of fascism?”; prompt on isolationism or keeping the U.S. out of WWII; prompt on white supremacy, white nationalism, racism, or anti-Semitism] <History - American>  Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by From the twisted minds behind Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman, (Charles Hang, Chinmay Kansara, Rohan Rai, Erik Tomasic) and Old, British, Both, or Neither (Joey Goldman, Jason Golfinos, John Lawrence, Mike Sorice)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. The Huns and Mongols may have practiced this ritual for intimidation. For 10 points each:
answers: head-flattening [accept artificial cranial deformation; accept any descriptive answer that describes flattening or elongating the head or forehead or synonymous terms]
parts: Name this aesthetic body modification, also practiced by the Mayans and Aztecs and made possible by the late fusion of certain bone plates. The Chinook placed babies in clamp-like cradleboards to induce it.
In Europe, flattened heads were associated with this city, home to the ill-fated Jean Calas. This former home of the Consistori del Gay Saber was ruled by several pro-Cathar counts named Raymond.

The oldest known example of head-flattening may be found in Iraq’s Shanidar cave site, which is located near this city. This city, built around a raised mound that hosts its namesake ancient citadel, is the power base for the Barzani family.

bonuses.leadin: In beta-thalassemia, toxic aggregates of hemoglobin sequester an isoform of this protein in the nucleus, rendering it incapable of protecting the transcription factor GATA-1 from cleavage by caspase-3. For 10 points each:
answers: Hsp70 [or heat shock protein 70; accept DnaK; prompt on heat-shock proteins; prompt on, but do not otherwise reveal, chaperones]
parts: Name this protein whose activity in prokaryotes is accelerated by J-domain molecules like DnaJ. Interaction with CHIP allows this protein to pass its defective clients to ubiquitination machinery in eukaryotes.
Hsp70 is one of these proteins that assists its clients in folding. GroEL is another of these proteins.

Overaction of the unfolded protein response leads to chaperone production and eventually apoptosis. Apoptosis is triggered by downregulation of this anti-apoptotic mitochondrial membrane protein, leading to cytochrome c liberation and activation of caspases.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the small Swiss town of Vevey, for 10 points each.
answers: Thabo Patrick Sefolosha [prompt on Thabo] <Mythology and Other>
parts: Daniel Peter invented milk chocolate in Vevey while collaborating with this company, which is headquartered in Vevey. This evil, evil owner of the Poland Spring and Deer Park water brands convinced the World Water Council to somehow reclassify “access to drinking water” from a “need” to a “want.”

This man spent the last two decades of his life in Vevey, where a “hungry” statue of him stares at a gigantic fork, perhaps awaiting the reclassification of his hunger into a “want.” The statue may reference this man’s lead role in The Gold Rush.

Vevey was the birthplace of this 13th overall pick of the 2006 NBA draft, who’s probably the best Swiss basketball player of all time unless things go really well for Clint Capela. Kyle Korver’s 2019 piece “Privileged” recounts how eight NYPD officers attacked this man and broke his leg for literally no reason in 2015.

bonuses.leadin: This essay includes declarations written in all-caps such as “FORM IS NEVER MORE THAN AN EXTENSION OF CONTENT” and “ONE PERCEPTION MUST IMMEDIATELY AND DIRECTLY LEAD TO A FURTHER PERCEPTION.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this 1950 essay that attempts to define its namesake “open” type of poetry, which is produced via “composition by field.”

Charles Olson, who wrote “Projective Verse,” and other poets of the projective movement, such as Robert Creeley, are often grouped in a literary movement named for this North Carolina college where many of them studied or taught.

“Projective Verse” was so important to this fellow poet that he quoted vast sections of it in his autobiography. This author of In the American Grain also wrote the poem “To Elsie,” which begins “the pure products of America / go crazy.”

bonuses.leadin: This text was revived thanks to a “royal” interpretation by Swami Vivekananda. For 10 points each:
answers: B.K.S. Iyengar [or Bellur Krishnamachar Sundararaja Iyengar]
parts: Name this text attributed to Patanjali, which classifies eight “limbs” of the title practice. It is the foundational text of a school of thought that largely sprang from the Samkhya school.

This man, who died in 2014, adopted principles from the Yoga Sutras in his bestseller Light on Yoga. This man’s namesake style of yoga was popularized thanks to the support of violinist Yehudi Menuhin.
Iyengar yoga and other forms of hatha yoga emphasize pranayama, or controlling this bodily action. Rhythmical control of this bodily process is often used to promote mindfulness in meditation.

bonuses.leadin: This railroad superseded the Louisa Railroad and the largely useless James River and Kanawha canal, and a stretch of it near Big Bend is closely tied to the legend of John Henry. For 10 points each:
answers: Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad [or C&O railroad; accept Chessie; accept Covington and Ohio Railroad even though it was never incorporated before becoming part of the C and O]
golden spike [accept last spike; prompt on partial answer] <History - American>
parts: Name this post-Civil War railroad backed by Collis P. Huntington, which adopted a kitten as its mascot. This key coal-hauling line connected the South to Midwestern industrial centers and is now part of CSX.

The C&O built on the work of this pioneering French-born civil engineer, who built the then-longest tunnel in the world through the Blue Ridge Mountains a decade before the invention of dynamite. This early adopter of the chalkboard was one of West Point’s first professors.

Before working on the C&O, Huntington was one of the Transcontinental Railroad’s “Big Four,” and thus got his name engraved on this object driven into Promontory Summit, Utah upon the line’s completion.

bonuses.leadin: A phrase from this text was used to title the 2018 MoMA retrospective of Adrian Piper’s work. For 10 points each:
answers: Critique of Pure Reason [or Kritik der Reine Vernunft]
funk [accept Funk Lessons; accept “Funky Drummer”] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name this text that Piper read aloud until she dissociated as part of the piece Food for the Spirit. Joseph Beuys put a copy of this book in a suitcase for his piece I Know No Weekend.
Thierry de Duve pitted modern art against the Critique of Pure Reason in a book titled for Kant “after” this artist, who invented conceptual art with his “readymades.”

After getting her PhD under John Rawls, Adrian Piper started performing a piece that consisted of teaching the audience how to dance to this genre of music. This genre, which originated in songs like “Cold Sweat,” titles a 1970 song that calls Clyde Stubblefield this kind of “Drummer.”

bonuses.leadin: This character runs away after being imprisoned in her room by her father, a country squire obsessed with fox hunting. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this young woman, who eventually arrives in London, where she narrowly avoids being sexually assaulted by Lord Fellamar. She becomes emotionally attached to her fur muff after learning that it was kissed by the title character.
After all of her trials and tribulations, Sophia Western eventually marries this title “foundling” of a novel by Henry Fielding.

This adjective is commonly applied to the works of Fielding and other English authors writing between the 1700s and 1740s. It takes its name from an Alexander Pope poem comparing George II to the title figure.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Schiff bases, for 10 points each.
answers: PLP [or pyridoxal-5′-phosphate or P5P; or pyridoxine, or vitamin B6]
parts: This reaction involves a Schiff base intermediate, formed when an amine attacks a non-enolizable aldehyde. The output of the reaction is a beta-amino·carbonyl compound, and an asymmetric form can be catalyzed by proline.

A Schiff base is formed between lysine and this enzyme cofactor in the active site of ALT and AST, enzymes that perform transamination reactions in the liver. This cofactor also assists in retro-Claisen reactions and beta- and gamma- decarboxylations of amino acids.
Schiff bases can act as these molecules, which bind to a central metal ion to form a coordination complex. These molecules can be classified by their denticity and cone angle.

bonuses.leadin: In anticipation of the Fall 2000 launch of this product, the worldwide price of coltan increased more than five-fold, which fueled ethnic violence in central Africa. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Sony videogame console for which Shadow of the Colossus was originally released.

Among the conflicts exacerbated by the PS2 was this one, named for a province on the DRC’s eastern border with Uganda that primarily pitted the Lendu against the Hema. For his role in this conflict, Thomas Lubanga Dyilo became the first person convicted by the ICC.

From late 2018 to early 2019, a resurgence of ethnic violence targeting the Hema population forced over 50,000 refugees to seek asylum in Uganda by crossing this body of water, once named Lake Mobutu Sese Seko.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about mud in Italian poetry:
parts: This author compared the world to fungo [FOON-goh], or mud, in his poem “To Himself.” An idyll by this poet ends with the line “E il naufragar m’è dolce in questo mare” [ayl NA-oo-frah-gar may DOHL-chay een kweh-stoh MAH-ray], or “shipwreck seems sweet to me in this sea.”
In this circle of Hell in the Inferno, Dante sees wrathful people biting each other in the mud. One of those people, Filippo Argenti, accosts Dante while Phleygas rows him across the river Styx.
This twentieth-century author’s poem “Buna” recounts the “monotonous horror” of the mud in Auschwitz. He also depicted the trauma of life in Auschwitz in his book If This Is a Man.

bonuses.leadin: This manifesto inspired Arhur Cayley’s remark that “all geometry is projective geometry.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1872 manifesto, which proposed to classify geometries in terms of the actions of transformation groups.

Felix Klein’s Erlangen program thus proposes to classify spaces based on these properties, which include homotopy and homology groups. One often proves that two spaces are not homeomorphic by calculating one of these properties for both spaces and showing that they’re not the same.

A classic example of that style of proof was Max Dehn’s invention of a namesake invariant to solve the third of these problems. Ennio di Giorgi and John Nash independently solved the nineteenth of these problems.

bonuses.leadin: The first post-Communist president of Croatia has a name indicating that one of his ancestors was one of these figures. For 10 points each:
answers: dragomans [prompt on interpreters or similar answers] (The Croatian president is Franjo Tudjman.)
Greek War of Independence [or Greek Revolution]
parts: Give this term for people who served as liaisons between Middle Eastern and European polities. Many of these people were killed in the Phanar quarter of Constantinople after the outbreak of a certain conflict.
Many dragomans were killed after the outbreak of this war that saw the death of Lord Byron. The secret society Filiki Eteria helped launch this war, which ended with the Treaty of Constantinople.
Napoleon’s favourite dragoman was this diplomat, who served as a translator in the Egyptian campaign before being sent on a namesake mission to orchestrate a Franco-Persian alliance.

bonuses.leadin: One thinker argued this method of “successive limited comparison” better described real-world bureaucratic policymaking than a “rational-comprehensive” model. For 10 points each:
answers: muddling through [accept “The Science of Muddling Through”; prompt on gradualism or incrementalism by reminding players we’re looking for the “title method”]
budgeting [accept The Politics of the Budgetary Process and zero-based budgeting; prompt on answers like allocating funds or financial planning]
parts: Identify this method, which titles a seminal 1959 article by political scientist Charles E. Lindblom.

Lindblom’s notion of “muddling through” was the theoretical basis for Aaron Wildavsky’s 1964 book on the politics of this political process. Peter Phyrr developed a “zero-based” form of it that was used under Jimmy Carter.
Frank Baumgartner and Bryan Jones challenged Lindblom’s incrementalism with this two-word theory, which takes its name from a theory of evolution developed by Niles Eldridge and Stephen Jay Gould.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker claimed that in addition to a physical struggle for power called the War of Maneuver, there is also a struggle for cultural influence, which he called the War of Position. For 10 points each:
answers: philosophy of praxis [or filosofia della praxis]
parts: Name this Italian philosopher whose Prison Notebooks collect the essays he wrote while imprisoned by the Fascists.

In the Prison Notebooks, Gramsci generally refers to Marxism using this three-word phrase, which alludes to one of the Aristotelian categories of human action. This phrase also titles the last section of the Notebooks.

Gramsci claimed that this earlier thinker is “the only man who has attempted to build up the philosophy of praxis scientifically.” This nineteenth-century Italian Marxist wrote Socialism and Philosophy and Essays on the Materialist Concept of History.

bonuses.leadin: The Cézanne retrospective at the 1907 iteration of this exhibition helped to inspire Analytical Cubism. For 10 points each:
answers: Société du Salon d’Automne [or Autumn Salon; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
Albert Gleizes [glehz] (The other co-author was Jean Metzinger.) <Arts - Visual>
parts: Name this annual art exhibition spearheaded by Frantz Jourdain in 1903. The term “Fauvism” was coined in response to its 1905 iteration.
In 1908, the Salon d’Automne infamously rejected this man’s painting Houses at l’Estaque, which led Louis Vauxcelles [voh-SELL] to coin the term “Cubism.”
This artist chronicled the fortunes of the Salon d’Automne in his The Epic: From Immobile Form to Mobile Form. This painter of Portrait of Jacques Nayral co-wrote the manifesto Du “Cubisme”.

bonuses.leadin: One of these characters tells the other about escaping from an ill-tempered slaughterhouse worker named Nicholas Snub-Nose. For 10 points each:
answers: dogs [their names are Cipión AND Berganza or Scipio AND Berganza]
hospitals [or the Hospital of the Resurrection in Valladolid] <Literature - European>
parts: Name or describe these two characters, who are secretly recorded by the eavesdropping Campuzano. One of them is told by the witch Cañizares that he is the son of the witch Montiela.
Those dogs, Cipión and Berganza, appear in “The Colloquy of the Dogs,” one of the Exemplary Novels by this Spanish author. He also created characters like Dulcinea.

In “The Colloquy of the Dogs,” Campuzano explains that he recorded the dogs’ conversation while staying in one of these places in Valladolid. Campuzano tells his friend Peralta how he entered this place after being betrayed by his wife in another of Cervantes’s Exemplary Novels, “The Deceitful Marriage.”

bonuses.leadin: LUPIN rem detectors may be utilized to minimize dead time loss in this technique. For 10 points each:
answers: coincidence detectors [or coincidence circuits; or coincidence devices; accept coincidence methods]
parts: Name this technique for measuring the energy spectra of neutron beams. Its setup typically consists of twelve polyethylene moderators stocked with boron-trifluoride proportional counters.

These systems developed by Walther Bothe, which consist of two inputs and one output, may be applied to reduce background photon noise during neutron detection. In neurobiology, the NMDA receptors of distal dendrites are said to act as these devices to induce long-term potentiation, by requiring multiple inputs before excitation.

This is the name for a medium that converts fast neutrons into thermal neutrons useful for sustaining a fission reaction in a nuclear reactor. Light water or graphite is often used as one of these materials.

bonuses.leadin: One of the earliest slave revolts in the Caribbean was led by Akwamu slaves in this colony in 1733. For 10 points each:
answers: Danish West Indies [or Dansk Vestindien; or Danish Antilles]
Second Anglo-Dutch War [prompt on partial answer; prompt on Second English War or Second Dutch War; accept Tweede Engelse Oorlog] <History - European>
parts: Name this colony that existed until 1917, at which point its islands were sold to the U.S. as main components of the U.S. Virgin Islands. By the mid-nineteenth century, half of its white population was Jewish.
The Danish West India Company was established during the reign of this Danish monarch. The longest-ruling Scandanavian king so far, he reigned throughout the whole of the Thirty Years’ War.

After its tenuous establishment in 1665, the Danish colony on St. Thomas was raided and depredated by both sides in this then-ongoing major naval war. A controversial victory in this war was dubbed “Holmes’s Bonfire.”

bonuses.leadin: A survey of pentatonicism “from the Eighteenth Century to [this composer]” was written by Jeremy Day-O’Connell. For 10 points each:
answers: G AND B-flat [accept in either order]
parts: Name this composer whose pentatonicism-dominated pieces include “Pagodas” and “The Girl with the Flaxen Hair.”
The first three notes of a C minor pentatonic scale are C, E-flat, and F. What are the remaining two notes?

Not all pentatonic scales are major or minor. This pentatonic scale can be approximated by the intervals “whole step, minor third, whole step, whole step,” although its whole steps are much wider than those in equal temperament, resulting in notes that are spaced almost evenly throughout the octave.
